{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3333471,"name":"jlawhead","username":"jlawhead","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/8e8cbc/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-15T01:15:24.954Z","cooked":"

We have MK4i neo and cancoder swerve modules with an arm driven by two NEOs. If we try to move the arm while driving, we lose control of the swerve until the arm stops moving. Having to stop to move the arm increases our cycle times for scoring way too much.

All motors have voltage limits.

Here’s our code: GitHub - AlphaOmegaOLA/2024Crescendo: FRC Team 7094's 2024 Java robot code for the FIRST Crescendo Competition. Drivebase is MK4i Swerve with NEOs, Cancoders, and a Pigeon 2.

Any suggestions are greatly appreciated!

Could you clarify what you mean by lose control? Does it drive a bad/weird way, does it drive randomly on its own, or does it not drive at all?

The arm should be it’s own subsystem, so that arm commands don’t interrupt your driving.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2024-03-15T04:25:38.088Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":104,"readers_count":103,"score":25.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":458718,"topic_slug":"competing-subsystems","display_username":"viggy96","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":31760,"username":"jlawhead","name":"jlawhead","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/8e8cbc/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24613,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"418 Mentor | Tries to be smart"},"post_url":"/t/competing-subsystems/458718/6","custom_user_title":"418 Mentor | Tries to be smart","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3333599,"name":"Joshua J","username":"thatnameistaken","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/t/57b2e6/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-15T04:28:55.610Z","cooked":"

setAngle() in Arm.java contains a while loop. This is holding up the entire command scheduler until it exits - meaning no other subsystems are updating at all until your arm gets to the requested angle.

Do not use loops in your commands/subsystems as a general rule, outside of things like for loops that you know will only run a handful of times. The command scheduler is already looping; nesting a loop further inside will prevent everything else in the scheduler from looping.

The simplest way to get things running better would be to change the arm commands from InstantCommand to RunCommand so the scheduler keeps calling setAngle() continuously; then change the while loops in setAngle() to simple if else statements (i.e. if the arm is to low, move it up; if it’s too high, move it down; else stay still). Make sure it’s only possible for each motor’s set() method to be called once per setAngle() call so they don’t stutter or get other weird effects when doing this.

There’s probably a better way to restructure this, but seeing as you have matches tomorrow morning, this is the quick and dirty solution. I haven’t fully looked over everything to verify no other oddities would come up, but at a quick glance I think it should give the behavior you’re expecting.

Edit: @jlawhead just tagging you because this didn’t properly reply to your post

viggy96:

Oh interesting…

Maybe I could have a look at the code. Is it public on GitHub?

It’s in the OP?

So eliminating the while loop improved things and got us through Friday in decent position. Thank you for that quick fix! We still had another logic error that wouldn’t let us go to intermediate positions from the floor angle, but it worked plenty well for us to compete at the Magnolia Regional in Mississippi. Our mentor team’s programmer from Team Fusion 364 helped us quickly implement a proper PID controller Saturday morning and now we get it and it worked great and we can build better robots. We made it all the way to the final game and took 2nd overall!
